qas.question: a larger three-byte SPLIT token with a seven-bit hub number, 12 bits of control flags, and a five-bit CRC were created to do what?
Rather than tie up the high-bandwidth USB bus sending data to a slower USB device, what happens?

answers.text: the nearest high-bandwidth capable hub receives a SPLIT token followed by one or two USB packets at high bandwidth

qas.question: How many bits of control flags did USB 2.0 add?

context: USB 2.0 also added a larger three-byte SPLIT token with a seven-bit hub number, <a2_0>12 bits<a2_0/> of control flags, and a five-bit CRC. This is used <a0_0>to perform split transactions<a0_0/>. Rather than tie up the high-bandwidth USB bus sending data to a slower USB device, <a1_0>the nearest high-bandwidth capable hub receives a SPLIT token followed by one or two USB packets at high bandwidth<a1_0/>, performs the data transfer at full or low bandwidth, and provides the response at high bandwidth when prompted by a second SPLIT token.
